\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{index::doc}}


The Python Data Visualizer (PyDV) is a replacement for ULTRA writtern in python. PyDV allows the presentation, manipulation, and analysis of 1D data sets, i.e. (x,y) pairs. Presentation refers to the capability to display, and make hard copies of data plots. Manipulation refers to the capability to excerpt, shift, and scale data sets. Analysis refers to the capability to combine data sets in various ways to create new data sets.

The principal object with which PyDV works is the curve. A curve is an object which consists of an array of x values, an array of y values, a number of points (the length of the x and y arrays), and an ASCII label. PyDV operates on curves.


\chapter{Users}
\label{\detokenize{index:users}}

\section{Release Notes For PyDV 3.0}
\label{\detokenize{release_notes_3.0:release-notes-for-pydv-3-0}}\label{\detokenize{release_notes_3.0:release-notes-3-0}}\label{\detokenize{release_notes_3.0::doc}}
Python 3 port with bug fixes and a lot of minor code refactoring.


\section{.pdvrc File Format}
\label{\detokenize{pdvrc:pdvrc-file-format}}\label{\detokenize{pdvrc:pdvrc}}\label{\detokenize{pdvrc::doc}}
\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
The \sphinxstylestrong{.pdvrc} file allows the user to initialize PyDV settings at startup time. PyDV expects the \sphinxstylestrong{.pdvrc} file to be located in the User’s Home Directory. The format of the \sphinxstylestrong{.pdvrc} file is ‘key=value’. Below are all of the currently recognized settings.
\end{sphinxadmonition}


\subsection{xlabel=label}
\label{\detokenize{pdvrc:xlabel-label}}
Set the label for the x-axis to label.


\subsection{ylabel=label}
\label{\detokenize{pdvrc:ylabel-label}}
Set the label for the y-axis to label.


\subsection{title=str}
\label{\detokenize{pdvrc:title-str}}
Set the title for the plot to str.


\subsection{key=ON \textbar{} OFF}
\label{\detokenize{pdvrc:key-on-off}}
Show the legend if key=ON, otherwise hide it if key=OFF.


\subsection{letters=ON \textbar{} OFF}
\label{\detokenize{pdvrc:letters-on-off}}
Show or hide letter markers on plotted curves.


\subsection{geometry=val1 val2 val3 val4}
\label{\detokenize{pdvrc:geometry-val1-val2-val3-val4}}
Change the PyDV window size and location in pixels where val1 is the x-size, val2 is the y-size, val3 is the x-location, and val4 is the y-location.


\subsection{initcommands=filename}
\label{\detokenize{pdvrc:initcommands-filename}}
Specify a file to run the initial commands.


\subsection{namewidth=width}
\label{\detokenize{pdvrc:namewidth-width}}
Change the width of teh first column of the menu and lst output.


\subsection{fontsize=size}
\label{\detokenize{pdvrc:fontsize-size}}
Change the font size


\subsection{lnwidth=width}
\label{\detokenize{pdvrc:lnwidth-width}}
Change the default line width of the curves.


\section{Getting started}
\label{\detokenize{getting_started:getting-started}}\label{\detokenize{getting_started:id1}}\label{\detokenize{getting_started::doc}}
This section gives a tutorial introduction to PyDV. A sample session is run which highlights the basic PyDV commands.

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
In PyDV commands, spaces are used to delimit items on the input line. More precisely items on a command line are
either space delimited, are preceded by a left parenthesis if the first item in a list, or terminated by a right
parenthesis if the last item in a list. Semicolons may be used to stack multiple commands on a single interactive
input line. In interactive mode, ranges of curve numbers or data-id’s may be indicated using colon notation.
For example, a:f or 5:9
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\section{I/O Commands}
\label{\detokenize{io_commands:i-o-commands}}\label{\detokenize{io_commands:io-commands}}\label{\detokenize{io_commands::doc}}
These commands access disk files either for reading or writing.

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxstylestrong{\textless{} \textgreater{}} = Required user input.

\sphinxstylestrong{{[}\textless{} \textgreater{}{]}} = Optional user input.

\sphinxstylestrong{{[}PyDV{]}} = Python Data Visualizer command-line prompt.
\end{sphinxadmonition}


\subsection{read}
\label{\detokenize{io_commands:read}}
Read curves from the specified ASCII file and optionally filter by regex. The next available prefix (see the prefix command) is automatically assigned the menu index of the first curve in each data file read. For column oriented (.gnu) files optionally specify the x-column number before the file name. \sphinxstylestrong{Shortcut: rd}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{PyDV}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{read} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{regex}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{n}{matches}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{col}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{filename}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{readcsv}
\label{\detokenize{io_commands:readcsv}}
Read CSV data file. The next available prefix (see the prefix command) is automatically assigned the menu index of the first curve in each data file read. For column oriented (.gnu) files optionally specify the x-column number before the file name. \sphinxstylestrong{Shortcut: rdcsv}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{PyDV}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{readcsv} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{col}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{filename}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{csv}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{run}
\label{\detokenize{io_commands:run}}
Execute a list of commands from a file.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{PyDV}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{run} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{filename}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{save}
\label{\detokenize{io_commands:save}}
Saves curves to a file in text format.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{PyDV}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{save} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{filename}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{curve}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n+nb}{list}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{savecsv}
\label{\detokenize{io_commands:savecsv}}
Save curves to file in comma separated values (CSV) format. Assumes all curves have the same x basis.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{PyDV}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{savecsv} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{filename}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{curve}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n+nb}{list}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\label{\detokenize{math_operations:abs}}

\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\subsection{average}
\label{\detokenize{math_operations:average}}
Average the specified curvelist over the intersection of their domains.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{PyDV}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{average} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{curve}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n+nb}{list}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{convolve}
\label{\detokenize{math_operations:convolve}}
Computes the convolution of the two given curves. This is similar to the slower \sphinxstylestrong{convolc} method in ULTRA that uses direct integration and minimal interpolations. \sphinxstylestrong{Shortcut:} convol

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{PyDV}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{convolve} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{curve1}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{curve2}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{points}\PYG{p}{]}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{convolveb}
\label{\detokenize{math_operations:convolveb}}
Computes the convolution of the two given curves and normalizing the second curve by the area under the curve. This computes the integrals directly which avoid padding and aliasing problems associated with FFT methods (it is however slower). \sphinxstylestrong{Shortcut:} convolb

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{PyDV}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{convolveb} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{curve1}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{curve2}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{points}\PYG{p}{]}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{convolvec}
\label{\detokenize{math_operations:convolvec}}
Computes the convolution of the two given curves with no normalization. This computes the integrals directly which avoid padding and aliasing problems associated with FFT methods (it is however slower). \sphinxstylestrong{Shortcut:} convolb

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{PyDV}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{convolveb} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{curve1}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{curve2}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{points}\PYG{p}{]}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\subsection{L1}
\label{\detokenize{math_operations:l1}}
Makes new curve that is the L1 norm of two args; the L1 norm is integral( \textbar{}curve1 - curve2\textbar{} ) over the interval {[}xmin,xmax{]}. Also prints value of integral to command-line.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{PyDV}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{L1} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{curve1}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{curve2}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{xmin}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{xmax}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{p}{]}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{L2}
\label{\detokenize{math_operations:l2}}
Makes new curve that is the L2 norm of two args; the L2 norm is integral( (curve1 - curve2)**2 )**(1/2) over the interval {[}xmin,xmax{]}. Also prints value of integral to command-line.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{PyDV}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{L2} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{curve1}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{curve2}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{xmin}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{xmax}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{p}{]}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{log}
\label{\detokenize{math_operations:log}}
Take the natural logarithm of the y values of the curves. If the optional argument \sphinxstyleemphasis{keep-neg-vals} is set to false, then zero and negative y-values will be discarded. \sphinxstyleemphasis{keep-neg-vals} is true by default. \sphinxstylestrong{Shortcut: ln}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]

\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
The p-norm is (integral( (curve1 - curve2)**p )**(1/p) over the interval {[}xmin, xmax{]},
where p = order.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\section{Environmental Inquiry Commands}
\label{\detokenize{env_inquiry_cmds:environmental-inquiry-commands}}\label{\detokenize{env_inquiry_cmds:env-inquiry-commands}}\label{\detokenize{env_inquiry_cmds::doc}}
These functions are provided to gain access to information about the state of the PyDV session. Information such as the state of global variables and system help packages is made available through these functions.

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxstylestrong{\textless{} \textgreater{}} = Required user input.

\sphinxstylestrong{{[} {]}} = Optional user input.

\sphinxstylestrong{{[}PyDV{]}:} = Python Data Visualizer command-line prompt.
\end{sphinxadmonition}


\subsection{help}
\label{\detokenize{env_inquiry_cmds:help}}
Return infroamtion about the specified command, variable, or command category. If no argument is supplied, return a list of available commands.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{PyDV}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{help} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{command}\PYG{p}{]}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{lst}
\label{\detokenize{env_inquiry_cmds:lst}}
Return a list of the curves currently displayed. A regular expression may be supplied for matching against the curve label to be listed.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{PyDV}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{lst} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{label}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{pattern}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{listannot}
\label{\detokenize{env_inquiry_cmds:listannot}}
List current annotations.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{PyDV}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{listannot}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{menu}
\label{\detokenize{env_inquiry_cmds:menu}}
Return a selection of the curves available for plotting. A regular expression may be supplied for matching against the curve label to be listed.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{PyDV}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{menu} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{label}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{pattern}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{\sphinxstylestrong{system - 2.4.2}}
\label{\detokenize{env_inquiry_cmds:system-2-4-2}}
Allows passing commands to the operating system. \sphinxstylestrong{Shortcut: ! or shell}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{PyDV}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{system} \PYG{n}{ls}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\section{Curve Inquiry Commands}
\label{\detokenize{curve_inquiry_cmds:curve-inquiry-commands}}\label{\detokenize{curve_inquiry_cmds:id1}}\label{\detokenize{curve_inquiry_cmds::doc}}
These functions provide a mechanism for obtaining information about specified curves.

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxstylestrong{\textless{} \textgreater{}} = Required user input.

\sphinxstylestrong{{[} {]}} = Optional user input.

\sphinxstylestrong{{[}PyDV{]}:} = Python Data Visualizer command-line prompt.
\end{sphinxadmonition}


\subsection{disp}
\label{\detokenize{curve_inquiry_cmds:disp}}
Display the y-values in the specified curve(s).

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{PyDV}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{disp} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{curve}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n+nb}{list}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{dispx}
\label{\detokenize{curve_inquiry_cmds:dispx}}
Display the x-values in the specified curve(s).

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]

\section{Environmental Control Commands}
\label{\detokenize{env_control_cmds:environmental-control-commands}}\label{\detokenize{env_control_cmds:env-control-commands}}\label{\detokenize{env_control_cmds::doc}}
These functions allow you to manipulate the environment of PyDV on a global level. They are useful to avoid repeated use of other commands or to change the state of PyDV in dramatic ways.

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxstylestrong{\textless{} \textgreater{}} = Required user input.

\sphinxstylestrong{{[} {]}} = Optional user input.

\sphinxstylestrong{{[}PyDV{]}:} = Python Data Visualizer command-line prompt.
\end{sphinxadmonition}


\subsection{alias}
\label{\detokenize{env_control_cmds:alias}}
Define a synonym for  an existing command.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{PyDV}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{alias} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{command}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{alias}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{custom}
\label{\detokenize{env_control_cmds:custom}}
Load a file of custom functions to extend PyDV. Functions must be of the form ‘def do\_commandname(self, line): …

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{PyDV}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{custom} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{file}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{name}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{debug}
\label{\detokenize{env_control_cmds:debug}}
Show debug tracebacks if True

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{PyDV}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{debug} \PYG{n}{on} \PYG{o}{\textbar{}} \PYG{n}{off}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{drop}
\label{\detokenize{env_control_cmds:drop}}
Start the Python Interactive Console

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{PyDV}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{drop}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{erase}
\label{\detokenize{env_control_cmds:erase}}
Erase all curves on the screen but leave the limits untouched. \sphinxstylestrong{Shortcut: era}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{PyDV}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{erase}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{kill}
\label{\detokenize{env_control_cmds:kill}}
Delete the specified entries from the menu.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{PyDV}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{kill} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n+nb}{all} \PYG{o}{\textbar{}} \PYG{n}{number}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n+nb}{list}\PYG{p}{]}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{namewidth}
\label{\detokenize{env_control_cmds:namewidth}}
Change the width of the first column of the \sphinxstylestrong{menu} and \sphinxstylestrong{lst} output.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{PyDV}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{namewidth} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{integer}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\section{Plot Control Commands}
\label{\detokenize{plot_control_cmds:plot-control-commands}}\label{\detokenize{plot_control_cmds:id1}}\label{\detokenize{plot_control_cmds::doc}}
These functions control the plotting characteristics of PyDV which affect all displayed curves.

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxstylestrong{\textless{} \textgreater{}} = Required user input.

\sphinxstylestrong{{[} {]}} = Optional user input.

\sphinxstylestrong{{[}PyDV{]}:} = Python Data Visualizer command-line prompt.
\end{sphinxadmonition}


\subsection{annot}
\label{\detokenize{plot_control_cmds:annot}}
Display text on the plot at point (x, y).

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{PyDV}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{annot} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{text}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{y}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{\sphinxstylestrong{bkgcolor - 2.4}}
\label{\detokenize{plot_control_cmds:bkgcolor-2-4}}
Change the background color of the plot, window, or both

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{PyDV}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{bkgcolor} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{plot} \PYG{o}{\textbar{}} \PYG{n}{window}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{n}{color}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{name} \PYG{o}{\textbar{}} \PYG{n}{reset}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{dashstyle}
\label{\detokenize{plot_control_cmds:dashstyle}}
Set the style of dash or dot dash lines. The python list is a list of integers, alternating how many pixels to turn on and off, for example:
\begin{quote}

{[}2, 2{]} : Two pixels on, two off (will result in a dot pattern).

{[}4, 2, 2, 2{]} : 4 on, 2 off, 2 on, 2 off (results in a dash-dot pattern).

{[}4, 2, 2, 2, 4, 2{]} : Gives a dash-dot-dash pattern.

{[}4, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2{]} : Gives a dash-dot-dot pattern.

See matplotlib ‘set\_dashes’ command for more information.
\end{quote}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{PyDV}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{dashstyle} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{curve}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n+nb}{list}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{dataid}
\label{\detokenize{plot_control_cmds:dataid}}
Show curve identifiers if True. \sphinxstylestrong{Alternative Form: data-id}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{PyDV}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{dataid} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{on} \PYG{o}{\textbar{}} \PYG{n}{off}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{domain}
\label{\detokenize{plot_control_cmds:domain}}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{PyDV}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{domain} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{low}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{lim}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{high}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{lim}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}

              \PYG{n}{OR}

\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{PyDV}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{domain} \PYG{n}{de}

\subsection{lnwidth}
\label{\detokenize{plot_control_cmds:lnwidth}}
Set the line widths of the specified curves. A line width of 0 will give the thinnest line which the host graphics system supports.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{PyDV}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{lnwidth} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{curve}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n+nb}{list}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{width}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{marker}
\label{\detokenize{plot_control_cmds:marker}}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]

\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{minorticks}
\label{\detokenize{plot_control_cmds:minorticks}}
Minor ticks are not visible by default. On will make the minor ticks visible and off will hide the minor ticks.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]

\section{Curve Control Commands}
\label{\detokenize{curve_control_cmds:curve-control-commands}}\label{\detokenize{curve_control_cmds:id1}}\label{\detokenize{curve_control_cmds::doc}}
These functions control the individual curves that are currently being displayed. They range in type from controlling the appearance of the curve to deleting it. They also include the “non-mathematical” mechanisms which may generate curves.

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxstylestrong{\textless{} \textgreater{}} = Required user input.

\sphinxstylestrong{{[} {]}} = Optional user input.

\sphinxstylestrong{{[}PyDV{]}:} = Python Data Visualizer command-line prompt.
\end{sphinxadmonition}


\subsection{\sphinxstylestrong{appendcurves - 2.4}}
\label{\detokenize{curve_control_cmds:appendcurves-2-4}}
Merge a list of curves over the union of their domains. Where the domains overlap, take the average of the curve’s y-values.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{PyDV}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{appendcurves} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{curve}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n+nb}{list}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{color}
\label{\detokenize{curve_control_cmds:color}}
Set the color of curves. Color names can be “blue”, “red”, etc., or “\#eb70aa”, a 6 digit set of hexadecimal red-green-blue values (RRGGBB). The entire set of HTML-standard color names is available. Type \sphinxstyleemphasis{showcolormap} to see the available named colors.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{PyDV}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{color} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{curve}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n+nb}{list}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{color}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{curve}
\label{\detokenize{curve_control_cmds:curve}}
Select curves from the menu for plotting. \sphinxstylestrong{Shortcut: cur}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{PyDV}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{curve} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{menu} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{regex}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n+nb}{list}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{of}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{menu}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{numbers}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{\sphinxstylestrong{dupx - 2.4}}
\label{\detokenize{curve_control_cmds:dupx-2-4}}
Duplicate x-values so that y=x for each of the specified curves.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{PyDV}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{dupx} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{curve}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n+nb}{list}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{linemarker}
\label{\detokenize{curve_control_cmds:linemarker}}
Set the marker symbol for the curves.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{PyDV}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{linemarker} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{curve}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n+nb}{list}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{marker}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{style}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{o}{\textbar{}} \PYG{o}{.} \PYG{o}{\textbar{}} \PYG{n}{circle} \PYG{o}{\textbar{}} \PYG{n}{square} \PYG{o}{\textbar{}} \PYG{n}{diamond}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{marker}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{size}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{p}{]}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
When setting this value through the interface or the curve object directly,
use ONLY matplotlib supported marker types. Matplotlib marker types are also
supported here as well. See matplotlib documentation on markers for further
information.
\end{sphinxadmonition}


\subsection{markerfacecolor}
\label{\detokenize{curve_control_cmds:markerfacecolor}}
Set the markerface color of curves. Color names can be “blue”, “red”, etc, or “\#eb70aa”, a 6 digit set of hexadecimal red-green-blue values (RRGGBB). The entire set of HTML-standard color names is available. Try “showcolormap” to see the available named colors.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{PyDV}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{markerfacecolor} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{curve}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n+nb}{list}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{color}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{name}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\subsection{line}
\label{\detokenize{curve_control_cmds:line}}
Generate a line with y = mx + b and an optional number of points.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{PyDV}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{line} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{m}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{b}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{xmin}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{xmax}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} pts]}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{linespoints}
\label{\detokenize{curve_control_cmds:linespoints}}
Plot curves as linespoints plots.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{PyDV}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{linespoints} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{curve}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n+nb}{list}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{n}{on} \PYG{o}{\textbar{}} \PYG{n}{off}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{makecurve}
\label{\detokenize{curve_control_cmds:makecurve}}
Generate a curve from two lists of numbers. Each list must be delimited by parentheses. \sphinxstylestrong{Alternative Form: make-curve}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{PyDV}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{makecurve} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n+nb}{list} \PYG{n}{of} \PYG{n}{x}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{values}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n+nb}{list} \PYG{n}{of} \PYG{n}{y}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{values}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{newcurve}
\label{\detokenize{curve_control_cmds:newcurve}}
Creates a new curve from an expression.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{PyDV}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{newcurve} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{numpy} \PYG{n}{expression}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
For convenience, both math and numpy modules have been imported into the namespace.
Just FYI, this feature is way outside the ULTRA syntax that PyDV is mostly based on.
EXAMPLE:

{[}PyDV{]}: newcurve sin(a.x*2*pi)/(h.y**2)

This creates a new curve according to the above expression. \sphinxstylestrong{Shortcut: nc}
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{warning}{Warning:}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Currently, newcurve is hard-wired to only handle single-letter labels.
Curve names used in the expression cannot be the @N type we use after
we run out of letters. Sorry (April 2015).

\item {} 
A common error is to forget the .x or .y on the curve label name.

\item {} 
All the arrays in your expression have to span the same domain! Currently (4/2015), newcurve
will generate a curve from different domains (with no error message), and that curve
will almost certainly not be what you intended.

\end{itemize}
\end{sphinxadmonition}


\subsection{random}
\label{\detokenize{curve_control_cmds:random}}
Generate random y values between -1 and 1 for the specified curves.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{PyDV}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{random} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{curve}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n+nb}{list}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\section{UI Features}
\label{\detokenize{ui_features:ui-features}}\label{\detokenize{ui_features:id1}}\label{\detokenize{ui_features::doc}}
The PyDV User Interface (UI) has many different windows and toolbar items that provide information and alternative ways of executing PyDV commands (see \hyperref[\detokenize{ui_features:pydv}]{Figure \ref{\detokenize{ui_features:pydv}}}). Below is a description of the different UI components that are available.

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\capstart

\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics[scale=0.4]{{pydv}.png}
\caption{PyDV User Interface}\label{\detokenize{ui_features:id3}}\label{\detokenize{ui_features:pydv}}\end{figure}


\subsection{Toolbar}
\label{\detokenize{ui_features:toolbar}}
An annotated toolbar for the PyDV UI is shown in \hyperref[\detokenize{ui_features:id2}]{Figure \ref{\detokenize{ui_features:id2}}}. Button \sphinxstylestrong{1} allows the user to reset the plot window to the original view, button \sphinxstylestrong{2} allows the user to step back to the previous view, and button \sphinxstylestrong{3} allows the user to step through to the next view. Button \sphinxstylestrong{4} allows panning the axis with the left mouse button and zooming the axis with the right mouse button. Button \sphinxstylestrong{5} allows zooming to a rectangle. Button \sphinxstylestrong{6} allows configuring of the subplots, button \sphinxstylestrong{7} is for saving the displayed figure, and button \sphinxstylestrong{8} is for editing curve lines and axes parameters. The area highlighted in \sphinxstylestrong{9} tracks the mouse location over the plot.

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\capstart

\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics[scale=0.5]{{toolbar}.png}
\caption{UI Toolbar}\label{\detokenize{ui_features:id4}}\label{\detokenize{ui_features:id2}}\end{figure}


\subsection{Help Menu}
\label{\detokenize{ui_features:help-menu}}
The \sphinxstylestrong{Help} menu contains three items for displaying information to the user. The \sphinxstylestrong{Copyright …} menu item displays the copyright information for PyDV (see \hyperref[\detokenize{ui_features:copyright}]{Figure \ref{\detokenize{ui_features:copyright}}}). The \sphinxstylestrong{About PyDV} window, \hyperref[\detokenize{ui_features:about-1}]{Figure \ref{\detokenize{ui_features:about-1}}}, displays information about the current release of PyDV and provides developer contact information. The \sphinxstylestrong{About Qt} window, \hyperref[\detokenize{ui_features:about-2}]{Figure \ref{\detokenize{ui_features:about-2}}}, displays information about the \sphinxstyleemphasis{Qt} version that PyDV is using.

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\capstart

\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics[scale=0.5]{{copyright}.png}
\caption{PyDV Copyright}\label{\detokenize{ui_features:id5}}\label{\detokenize{ui_features:copyright}}\end{figure}

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\capstart

\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics[scale=0.5]{{about1}.png}
\caption{About PyDV Window}\label{\detokenize{ui_features:id6}}\label{\detokenize{ui_features:about-1}}\end{figure}

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\capstart

\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics[scale=0.5]{{about2}.png}
\caption{About Qt Window}\label{\detokenize{ui_features:id7}}\label{\detokenize{ui_features:about-2}}\end{figure}


\subsection{View Menu}
\label{\detokenize{ui_features:view-menu}}
The \sphinxstylestrong{View} menu contains the \sphinxstylestrong{List} and \sphinxstylestrong{Menu} dialogs. The \sphinxstylestrong{List} dialog displays the information from the \sphinxstylestrong{list} command and also allows the user to deleted selected curves from the plot window (see \hyperref[\detokenize{ui_features:list}]{Figure \ref{\detokenize{ui_features:list}}}).

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\capstart

\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics[scale=0.5]{{list}.png}
\caption{List of plotted curves}\label{\detokenize{ui_features:id8}}\label{\detokenize{ui_features:list}}\end{figure}

The \sphinxstylestrong{Menu} dialog lists the available curves read from a file. The user can delete or plot curves from this dialog (see \hyperref[\detokenize{ui_features:menu}]{Figure \ref{\detokenize{ui_features:menu}}}).

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\capstart

\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics[scale=0.5]{{menu}.png}
\caption{List of available curves}\label{\detokenize{ui_features:id9}}\label{\detokenize{ui_features:menu}}\end{figure}

\index{convolve() (in module pydvpy)@\spxentry{convolve()}\spxextra{in module pydvpy}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{pydv:pydvpy.convolve}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{pydvpy.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{convolve}}}{\emph{c1}, \emph{c2}, \emph{npts=100}}{}
Compute and return the convolution of two real curves:
-
-   (g*h)(x) = Int(-inf, inf, dt, g(t)*h(x-t))
-
The Fourier Transform is used to perform the convolution.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{curves} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{pydvif}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{read}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{testData.txt}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{newcurve} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{pydvif}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{convolve}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{curves}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{curves}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{c1}} ({\hyperref[\detokenize{pydv:curve.Curve}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{Curve}}}}}) \textendash{} (N,) The first curve

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{c2}} ({\hyperref[\detokenize{pydv:curve.Curve}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{Curve}}}}}) \textendash{} (M,) The second curve

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{npts}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{int}}) \textendash{} the number of points used to create a uniform temporal spacing

\end{itemize}

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
nc: Curve \textendash{} the convolution of the two curves c1 and c2

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{convolve\_int() (in module pydvpy)@\spxentry{convolve\_int()}\spxextra{in module pydvpy}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{pydv:pydvpy.convolve_int}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{pydvpy.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{convolve\_int}}}{\emph{c1}, \emph{c2}, \emph{norm=True}, \emph{npts=100}}{}
Computes the convolution of the two curves (c1, c2). The integrals are computed directly which avoid padding
and aliasing problems associated with FFT methods (it is however slower).
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{c1}} ({\hyperref[\detokenize{pydv:curve.Curve}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{Curve}}}}}) \textendash{} (N,) The first curve

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{c2}} ({\hyperref[\detokenize{pydv:curve.Curve}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{Curve}}}}}) \textendash{} (M,) The second curve

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{norm}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{bool}}) \textendash{} if true then the result is normalized to unit area.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{npts}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{int}}) \textendash{} the number of points

\end{itemize}

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
nc: Curve \textendash{} the convolution of the two curves c1 and c2

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{convolveb() (in module pydvpy)@\spxentry{convolveb()}\spxextra{in module pydvpy}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{pydv:pydvpy.convolveb}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{pydvpy.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{convolveb}}}{\emph{c1}, \emph{c2}, \emph{npts=100}}{}~\begin{description}
\item[{Computes the convolution of the two given curves}] \leavevmode\begin{description}
\item[{(g*h)(x) = Int(-inf, inf, dt*g(t)*h(x-t))/}] \leavevmode
Int(-inf, inf, dt*h(t))

\end{description}

\end{description}

This computes the integrals directly which avoid padding and aliasing
problems associated with FFT methods (it is however slower).
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{c1}} ({\hyperref[\detokenize{pydv:curve.Curve}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{Curve}}}}}) \textendash{} (N,) The first curve

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{c2}} ({\hyperref[\detokenize{pydv:curve.Curve}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{Curve}}}}}) \textendash{} (M,) The second curve

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{npts}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{int}}) \textendash{} the number of points

\end{itemize}

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
Curve \textendash{} the convolution of the two curves c1 and c2 using integration and normalizing c2

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{correlate() (in module pydvpy)@\spxentry{correlate()}\spxextra{in module pydvpy}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{pydv:pydvpy.correlate}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{pydvpy.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{correlate}}}{\emph{c1}, \emph{c2}, \emph{mode='valid'}}{}
Computes the cross-correlation of two 1D sequences (c1.y and c2.y) as defined by numpy.correlate.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{c1}} ({\hyperref[\detokenize{pydv:curve.Curve}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{Curve}}}}}) \textendash{} The first curve with 1D input sequence c1.y

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{c2}} ({\hyperref[\detokenize{pydv:curve.Curve}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{Curve}}}}}) \textendash{} The second curve with 1D input sequence c2.y

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{mode}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} 
\{‘full’, ‘same’, ‘valid’\}, optional
‘full’:
\begin{quote}

By default, mode is ‘full’.  This returns the convolution
at each point of overlap, with an output shape of (N+M-1,). At
the end-points of the convolution, the signals do not overlap
completely, and boundary effects may be seen.
\end{quote}
\begin{description}
\item[{’same’:}] \leavevmode
Mode ‘same’ returns output of length \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{max(M, N)}}.  Boundary
effects are still visible.

\item[{’valid’:}] \leavevmode
Mode ‘valid’ returns output of length
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{max(M, N) - min(M, N) + 1}}.  The convolution product is only given
for points where the signals overlap completely.  Values outside
the signal boundary have no effect.

\end{description}


\end{itemize}

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
Curve \textendash{} the cross-correlation of c1.y and c2.y

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{create\_plot() (in module pydvpy)@\spxentry{create\_plot()}\spxextra{in module pydvpy}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{pydv:pydvpy.create_plot}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{pydvpy.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{create\_plot}}}{\emph{curvelist}, \emph{**kwargs}}{}
Create a plot from of the curves in curvelist. The available keyword arguments are:
* Filename: fname=’myFile’
* Save Format: ftype=’pdf’
* Plot Title: title=’My Title’
* X-Axis Label: xlabel=’X’
* Y-Axis Label: ylabel=’Y’
* Show/Hide Plot Legend: legend=True
* Plot Style: stylename=’ggplot’
* Show X-Axis in log scale: xls=True
* Show Y-Axis in log scale: yls=True
* Set the width of the figure in inches: fwidth=1.2
* Set the height of the figure in inches: fheight=2.1

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{curves} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{pydvif}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{read}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{testData.txt}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}

\index{disp() (in module pydvpy)@\spxentry{disp()}\spxextra{in module pydvpy}}

\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{pydv:pydvpy.disp}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{pydvpy.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{disp}}}{\emph{c}, \emph{domain=True}}{}
Create a string formatted list of the curve’s x-values if domain is True, otherwise y-values.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{c} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{pydvif}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{span}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{10}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{yvalues} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{pydvif}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{disp}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{c}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k+kc}{False}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{c}} \textendash{} The given curve

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{domain}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{bool}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{, }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{optional}}) \textendash{} if True, display the x-values of the curve. Otherwise, display the y-values of the curve

\end{itemize}

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
list \textendash{} The list of x- or y-values as strings

\end{description}\end{quote}

\index{fft() (in module pydvpy)@\spxentry{fft()}\spxextra{in module pydvpy}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{pydv:pydvpy.fft}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{pydvpy.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{fft}}}{\emph{c}, \emph{n=None}, \emph{axis=-1}, \emph{norm=None}}{}
Compute the one-dimensional discrete Fourier Transform for the x- or y-values of c.

This function computes the one-dimensional \sphinxstyleemphasis{n}-point discrete Fourier
Transform (DFT) with the efficient Fast Fourier Transform (FFT)
algorithm {[}CT{]}.
\begin{description}
\item[{c}] \leavevmode{[}curve{]}
Curve with x- or y-values as input array, can be complex.

\item[{n}] \leavevmode{[}int, optional{]}
Length of the transformed axis of the output.
If \sphinxtitleref{n} is smaller than the length of the input, the input is cropped.
If it is larger, the input is padded with zeros.  If \sphinxtitleref{n} is not given,
the length of the input along the axis specified by \sphinxtitleref{axis} is used.

\item[{axis}] \leavevmode{[}int, optional{]}
Axis over which to compute the FFT.  If not given, the last axis is
used.

\item[{norm}] \leavevmode{[}\{None, “ortho”\}, optional{]}
Normalization mode (see \sphinxtitleref{numpy.fft}). Default is None.

\end{description}
\begin{description}
\item[{out}] \leavevmode{[}Curve tuple{]}
Two curves with the real and imaginary parts.

\end{description}
\begin{description}
\item[{IndexError}] \leavevmode
if \sphinxtitleref{axes} is larger than the last axis of \sphinxtitleref{a}.

\end{description}

FFT (Fast Fourier Transform) refers to a way the discrete Fourier
Transform (DFT) can be calculated efficiently, by using symmetries in the
calculated terms.  The symmetry is highest when \sphinxtitleref{n} is a power of 2, and
the transform is therefore most efficient for these sizes.

The DFT is defined, with the conventions used in this implementation, in
the documentation for the \sphinxtitleref{numpy.fft} module.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{curves} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{pydvif}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{read}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{testData.txt}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{realcurve}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{imagcurve} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{pydvif}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{fft}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{curves}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{getymax() (in module pydvpy)@\spxentry{getymax()}\spxextra{in module pydvpy}}

\begin{fulllineitems}

Get the maximum y-value for the curve within the specified domain.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{c}} \textendash{} the curve

\item {}

Make a new curve that is the L1 norm of curve c1 and  curve c2.

\index{powr() (in module pydvpy)@\spxentry{powr()}\spxextra{in module pydvpy}}

\begin{fulllineitems}

\index{readcsv() (in module pydvpy)@\spxentry{readcsv()}\spxextra{in module pydvpy}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{pydv:pydvpy.readcsv}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{pydvpy.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{readcsv}}}{\emph{fname}, \emph{xcol=0}, \emph{verbose=False}}{}
Load a csv (comma separated values) data file, add parsed curves to
a curvelist. ‘\#’ is the comment character.  First uncommented line must
be the column labels.  We assume the first column is the x-data, every
other column is y-data.  We also assume all columns are the same length.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{curves} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{readcsv}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{testData.csv}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{fname}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} csv filename

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{xcol}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{int}}) \textendash{} x-column number for column oriented (.gnu) files

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{verbose}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{bool}}) \textendash{} prints the error stacktrace when True

\end{itemize}

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
list \textendash{} the list of curves from the csv file

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{append() (in module curve)@\spxentry{append()}\spxextra{in module curve}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{pydv:curve.append}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{curve.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{append}}}{\emph{a}, \emph{b}}{}
Merge curve a and curve b over the union of their domains. Where domains overlap, take
the average of the curve’s y-values.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{a}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{curve}}) \textendash{} Curve A

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{b}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{curve}}) \textendash{} Curve B

\end{itemize}

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
a new curve resulting from the merging of curve a and curve b

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{getinterp() (in module curve)@\spxentry{getinterp()}\spxextra{in module curve}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{pydv:curve.getinterp}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{curve.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{getinterp}}}{\emph{a}, \emph{b}, \emph{left=None}, \emph{right=None}, \emph{samples=100}, \emph{match='domain'}}{}
Gets the interpolated and domain matched versions of the two curves.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{a}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{curve}}) \textendash{} Curve A

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{b}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{curve}}) \textendash{} Curve B

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{left}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{float}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{, }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{optional}}) \textendash{} Value to return for \sphinxtitleref{x \textless{} a.x{[}0{]}}, default is \sphinxtitleref{a.y{[}0{]}}.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{right}} \textendash{} Value to return for \sphinxtitleref{x \textgreater{} a.x{[}-1{]}}, default is \sphinxtitleref{a.y{[}-1{]}}.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{\{'domain'}}\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{,}}\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{'step'\}}}\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{,}}\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{optional}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{match}}) \textendash{} A string indicating how to interpolate the two curves

\end{itemize}

\item[{Type}] \leavevmode
right: float, optional

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
curve pair \textendash{} the interpolated and domain matched versions of a and b

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{interp1d() (in module curve)@\spxentry{interp1d()}\spxextra{in module curve}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{pydv:curve.interp1d}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{curve.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{interp1d}}}{\emph{a}, \emph{num=100}, \emph{retstep=False}}{}
Gets the interpolated values of the curve with the specified number of samples.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{a}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{curve}}) \textendash{} Curve A

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{num}} \textendash{} Number of samples to generate. Default is 100. Must be non-negative.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{retstep}} \textendash{} return the spacing between samples

\end{itemize}

\item[{Type}] \leavevmode
num: int, optional

\item[{Type}] \leavevmode
retstep: bool, optional

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
ia: curve \textendash{} the interpolated and dimensions matched version of a
step: float, optional \textendash{} only returned if retstep is True. Size of the spacing between samples

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{emptyline() (pdv.Command method)@\spxentry{emptyline()}\spxextra{pdv.Command method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{pydv:pdv.Command.emptyline}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{emptyline}}}{}{}
Called when an empty line is entered in response to the prompt.

If this method is not overridden, it repeats the last nonempty
command entered.
